metadata.title: The performance of nano urchin-like NiCo2O4 modified activated carbon as air cathode for microbial fuel cell

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Power Sources
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ jpowsour
The performance of nano urchin-like NiCo2O4 modified activated carbon as air cathode for microbial fuel cell
Baochao Ge a, b, Kexun Li a, b, *, Zhou Fu a, b, Liangtao Pu a, b, Xi Zhang a, b, Ziqi Liu a, b, Kan Huang c
a The College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China b MOE Key Laboratory of Pollution Processes and Environmental Criteria, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China c Nissan Technical Center North America, Farmington Hills, MI 48331, USA
h i g h l i g h t s
Urchin-like spinel NiCo2O4 was doped in AC air cathode catalyst layer. The MPD of treated MFC was 1730 ± 14 mW m 2, 2.28 times higher than the control. The ORR and kinetics constant were increased due to a four-electron pathway. The mesopores electrode provided more active sites in the catalyst layer.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 18 August 2015 Received in revised form 22 October 2015 Accepted 2 November 2015 Available online xxx
Keywords: Microbial fuel cell Urchin-like NiCo2O4 Oxygen reduction reaction Air cathode
* Corresponding author. The College of Environmen Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China.
E-mail address: likx@nankai.edu.cn (K. Li).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.11.003 0378-7753/© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
A nano urchin-like NiCo2O4 has been successfully synthesized via a facile and scalable hydrothermal method. A NiCo2O4 modified active carbon air cathode was designed, optimized and fabricated. The maximum power density of the microbial fuel cell with newly developed cathode is 2.28 time higher than bare active carbon and is comparable to the commercial available Pt/C, reaching 1730 ± 14 mWm 2. The modified active carbon showed remarkable improvement in activity towards the oxygen reduction reaction, which was due to the lower charger transfer, lower activation barrier, and higher exchange current density. Electrochemical evaluation showed a direct four-electron the oxygen reduction reaction on NiCo2O4 modified active carbon, compared to a two-stage process on bare active carbon. The nonprecious NiCo2O4 could be considered as a promising alternative to the costly Pt.
© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Microbial fuel cells (MFCs) are devices that use microorganism to oxidize organic materials to generate electricity [1]. MFCs are being constructed with various materials and operated under a range of conditions that include difference in pH value, electrode surface area, reactor size and operation time etc. To simplify the construction, single-chamber MFC is commonly adopted, in which anode chamber is separated from the air-cathode chamber by a gas diffusion layer. Oxygen is the most suitable electron acceptor for MFCs. However, due to the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on plain carbon, catalyzedmaterials is highly desired, among
tal Science and Engineering,
which Pt has been proved to be an efficient and indispensable element [2].
Even though the wide application of Pt as active materials, intensive researches are conducted to seek for less costly but effective alternatives, such as modified carbon materials [3,4]. A variety of non-precious metals such as Ni, Co, Fe [5], and their oxides like Fe3O4 [6] and MnO2 [7]. Metal oxides with spinel structure have shown the extraordinary power performance and durability [8,9]. For example, manganese-cobalt oxides modified graphene has been reported as an advanced ORR catalyst [10]. Catalyzed by spinel Co3O4/nitrogen-doped graphene, a maximum power density of 1340 ± 10mWm 2 has been demonstrated [11]. Cheng et al. also reported that CoxMn3 xO4 with nanocrystalline spinel structure exhibited a remarkable ORR catalytic activity [12]. Spinel oxides with mixed valence states have been shown as promising alternatives to platinum in methanol and boro-hybride fuel cells [13].
Their considerable ORR catalytic activities could be attributed to the mixed semiconducting properties of spinel oxides. The cations can change their oxidation states, which lead to the formation of “electroconductivity chains” by providing the flow of electrons [14]. Even though the impressive electrocatalytic activities of spinel metal oxides, the low electronic conductivity limited their application as air-breath cathode materials in MFCs. Integrating highly activemetal oxides with high conductive carbonmaterials such like carbon cloth and active carbon is commonly used to remove the hurdle of low conductivity.
NiCo2O4 possessed much better electrical conductivity and higher redox activity compared to single NiO and Co3O4 [15] In this study, nano spinel urchin-like NiCo2O4 was synthesized by a
hydrothermal method, which was used as the active ORR material in cathode. Comprehensive characterizations including maximum power density were carried to thoroughly investigate the MFC system.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of NiCo2O4
sections.text:
All chemicals used in this study were in analytical grade and used without further purification. In a typical fabrication, 1.164 g Co(NO3)2$6H2O and 2.332 g Ni(NO3)2$6H2O were dissolved into 40 mL deionized water, followed by the adding 3.84 g (NH2)2CO.
iCo2O4; (b, d, e) TEM image of NiCo2O4; (c) Typical morphology of urchin-like sphere; area diffraction(SAED).
The mixture was stirred for 3 h at room temperature and then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with the volume of 100mL. The autoclavewas filled upwith deionizedwater to 80% of its total volume capacity. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 170 C with heating rate of 2.5 C/min. The reaction lasts for 8 h, then air cooled to room temperature. The precipitates were collected by centrifugal filtration, followed by thorough wash with deionized water and absolute ethanol, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 C for 12 h. The final product was calcined in a muffle stove at 500 C in air for 3 h to convert into the crystalline NiCo2O4.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of air-cathode
sections.text: Three parallel samples were prepared to ensure the reproducibility of each process. All the air-cathodes were made by a rollingepress method as previously described [16]. The cathode has triple layers, including a gas diffusion layer, a catalyst layer and a stainless steel mesh. Typically, the catalyst layer was made by mixing NiCo2O4 with the active carbon (2100 m2 g 1, Yihuan Carbon Co. Ltd., Fujian, China), and PTFE (60%wt.%, Hesen, shanghai, China) and then subjected to rolling-press. The amount of NiCo2O4 in the composites were 0 wt.%, 5 wt.%, 10 wt.% and 15 wt.%, and the final products were designated to be AC, AC-NCO1, AC-NCO2 and AC-NCO3, respectively. The gas diffusion layer was prepared by the same procedure of catalyst layer, but only include Carbon black (Jin qiu shi chemistry co. Ltd., Tianjin, China) and PTFE with amass ratio of 3:7. The three individual layers were laminated in parallel and rolling pressed to form an air cathode. The obtained air cathode which was dried at 30 C for 12 h to remove the solvent residual.

sections.heading: 2.3. Construction of MFC
sections.text:
The single-chamber MFC was configured by an inner cylindrical chamber with a diameter of 3 cm and volume of 28 mL. Both anode and cathode had a surface area of 7 cm2 and were placed with a spacing of 4 cm. The anode was made of a carbon felt, in which a corrosion resistive titanium wire was embedded to connect the anode and cathode to form external circuit. The chamber was filled with 50 mM phosphate buffered saline (PBS: NH4Cl 0.31 g L 1, KCl 0.13 g L 1, NaH2PO4$2H2O 3.321 g L 1, Na2HPO4$12H2O 10.305 g L 1), 12.5 mL L 1 trace minerals and 5 mL L 1 vitamins. In the first 3e4 cycles (one cycle lasted 1e2 days) of culture, domestic wastewater with external resistance of 1000 U was used as the inoculums. The operation temperature of MFC was maintained at 30 C and the voltage was recorded at every minute by data
Fig. 2. Nitrogen adsorptionedesorption isotherm loop (
acquisition card (MorpheusElectronic Co. Ltd, Beijing, China) to ensure the reproducibility.

sections.heading: 2.4. Structural characterization
sections.text: X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a D/max-2500 X-ray generator. The X-ray intensity was measured over a diffraction 2- theta angle from 10 to 80 with a velocity of 0.02 min 1. To obtain the information of oxidation state of Ni and Co on the surface of AC, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra was collected and fitted. The measurements were carried out using an XPS spectrometer (K-Aepna, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). Specific surface area measurement of the catalyst layer was conducted using a BrunauereEmmetteTeller method with an adsorption meter (ASAP2020/Tristar 3000, MICROMERITICS). The surface morphology and microstructure of prepared NiCo2O4 were examined by field emission transmission electron microscope (FE-TEM) on JSM-7500F.

sections.heading: 2.5. Electrochemical characterization
sections.text:
To measure the polarization curves and power density, the external resistance of MFC was varied from 9000 to 50 U. MFCs were stabilized for 6 h at open circuit potential before each measurement and the cell potential was record for 10 min at each resistance to ensure a reliable voltage profile. All data were recorded by a potentiostat (VersaSTAT 3, Princeton Applied Research, USA). A classic three-electrode system was employed, in which Ag/ AgCl and platinum sheet (1 cm2) were used as reference electrode, respectively. The as-prepared cathode described in section 2.2 served as the working electrode. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted to measure the ORR performance. LSV was carried out in potential range from OCV to 0.3 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s 1 in 50 mM PBS (pH ¼ 7). Tafel plot was also recorded by sweeping from overpotential of 0 Ve100 mV at scan rate of 1 mV s 1 to determine the intrinsic current. The empirical Tafel equation can be expressed as lgi ¼ lgi0 bnFh/2.303RT [16]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was measured over a frequency range from 100 kHz to 10 mHz at OCV.
Rotating disk electrode (RRDE-3A, ALS, Japan) was used to load the NiCo2O4 catalyst. 2 mg catalyst was ultrasonically dispersed into 2.5 mL ethanol and 0.5 mL 0.05 wt.% Nafion solution to form a catalyst ink. Desired amount of the catalyst ink were dripped on the glassy carbon electrode and dried at room temperature. ORR was measured in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH by linear scanning from 0.2
a) and pore size distribution curve of NiCo2O4 (b).
to 0.8 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) at scan rate of 5 mV s 1 [17].
3. Results and discussion
3.1. Structural characterization
XRD pattern of NiCo2O4 was shown in Fig. 1a. The four main characteristic diffraction peaks at 36.7 , 44.6 , 64.5 and 76.5 were assigned to (311), (400), (440) and (533) planes of NiCo2O4, respectively. Furthermore, NiCo2O4 featured a spinel type cubic structure of Fd-3 m space group, in good agreement with standard
power diffraction patterns of NiCo2O4 (JCPDS No: 20-0781). The lack of diffraction peaks from impurities suggested the high purity of NiCo2O4.
TEM images of NiCo2O4 were shown in Fig. 1bec to give further insight into the surface morphology and microstructure. Fig. 1b displayed a typical low-magnification TEM image, in which NiCo2O4 featured as a urchin-like sphere with a diameter of 300 nm. Numerous nanorods can be clearly seen grown radially from the center. Fig. 1dee showed the high resolution TEM images of urchin-like NiCo2O4. The diameter and length of individual nanorods were measured to be 5e50 nm and several hundred nm, respectively. It was reported that the diameter of nanowires NiCo2O4 [18] and nanowall NiCo2O4 [19] were just 8 nm and 10 nm, respectively, so the diameter of the length was similar. HRTEM images are presented in Fig. 1feg. The lattice fringes with d-spacing of 0.20 and 0.24 nm can be indexed to the (400) and (311) planes of NiCo2O4, respectively. The selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in Fig. 1h displayed a nice dot pattern associated to (400), (400), (311) and (533) planes, in a good agreement with XRD findings and further confirmed the successful preparation of crystalline NiCo2O4. Detailed information of specific surface areas and pore structure were characterized by BrunauereEmmetteTeller method, and results were shown in Fig. 2. The isothermal profiles exhibited a typical Langmuir type IV with an obvious hysteresis loop, indicating a mesoporous structure. The surface area of asprepared NiCo2O4 was measured to be 102.4 m2 g 1, larger than reported straw-like NiCo2O4 nanorod bundles (33.05 m2 g 1) [20], flower-like NiCo2O4 (80.1 m2 g 1) [21], urchin-like NiCo2O4 sphere
(92.26 m2 g 1) [22] and nanoflakes (38.22 m2 g 1) [19]. In Fig. 2b, the average pore size was measured to be 46.8 nm, which was in agreement with the TEM observations, and larger than that of NiCo2O4 reported by Ding et al. [23]. The mesoporous structure of as-prepared NiCo2O4 not only improve the gas adsorption/ desorption behavior on the surface, but also enhance the mass transport of small molecules and ions within the composites [24].
The outstanding electrocatalytic activity of NiCo2O4 is most likely ascribed to the increased number of active sites [25]. XPS technique was applied to probe the valence information of Ni and Co, and the results were shown in Fig. 3. The typical signals of O1s, Co2p and Ni2p core levels were detected. The O1s spectra, presented in Fig. 3a, showed four oxygen contributions, denoted as 1 (529.0 eV), 2 (530.5 eV), 3 (531.8 eV), and 4 (533.1 eV), belonging to the typical metaleoxygen bonds [26]. The high resolution of Co2p spectrum in Fig. 3bwas deconvoluted into two spineorbit doublets, characteristics of Co2þ and Co3þ, and two shakeup satellites, as presented in Fig. 3b. The Ni 2p was also fitted with two spineorbit doublets and two shakeup satellites, indicating the presence of Ni2þ and Ni3þ. The valence information gained from XPS suggested the surface of NiCo2O4 contains Co2þ, Co3þ, Ni2þ and Ni3þ species. The quantitative analysis showed the mole ratio of Co3þ to Co2þ and Ni3þ to Ni2þ were 1.44:1, and 1.63:1, respectively, and the total ratio of (Co3þþNi3þ) to (Co2þþ Ni2þ)was 1.57:1. Thus the composite of NiCo2O4 could be considered as (Ni2þCo2þ) (Ni3þCo3þ)1.57O4. It was reported that the redox couples of Co2þ/Co3þ and Ni2þ/Ni3þ in the structures can afford as rich electroactive sites for ORR, which contribute to the notable electrocatalytic performance of NiCo2O4 materials [27]. And the trivalent species in the spinel metal oxides was believed to function as active sites for activating adsorbed O2 [28]. Therefore, the excellent electrocatalytic activity of NiCo2O4 could be ascribed to the much greater number of active sites on their surface [29].

sections.heading: 3.2. Evaluation of performance of MFC
sections.text:
The stable power density and polarization curves were collected after a month equilibration and the individual polarization curves of cathode and anodewere also recorded, presented in Fig. 4. Fig. 4b showed that the anode potentials of four MPCs were almost the same through the current density range, indicating a similar polarization resistance, while significant difference in i-V behavior were observed in the cathodes. It can be clearly seen that bare AC
Fig. 5. (a) LSVs of the bare AC and NiCo2O4 modified AC. (b) Nyquist plots of EIS of bare AC circuit.
cathode has the much larger resistance than NiCo2O4 modified AC, suggesting the enhanced ORR capability by adding NiCo2O4. The polarization resistances of three AC-NCO were close, among them AC-NCO2 exhibited a slightly small value; detailed investigation will be discussed in section 3.3.
The overall cell performance and power density were displayed in Fig. 4. The worst performance of bare AC cathode can be anticipated due to its severe polarization. The maximum power density (MPD) of AC-NCO2 was calculated to be 1730 ± 14 mW m 2, more than twice larger than bare AC (760 ± 20mWm 2), and higher than reported commercial Pt/C (1470 mW m 2) [11], MnO2(1554 mW m 2) [30], Co3O4/N-G (1340 mW m 2) [11] and Cu2O [31]. Besides, AC-NCO3 and AC-NCO1 also exhibited remarkable MPD of 1574 ± 25 mW m 2 and 1481 ± 32 mW m 2, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical characterization of air cathode
sections.text:
LSVwas used to evaluate the effect of NiCo2O4 on ORR, shown in Fig. 5a. The onset potential (vs. Ag/AgCl) of AC-NCO2 was measured to be 0.236 V, higher than that of AC (0.199 V). And the onset potential of AC-NCO1 is almost the same as AC-NCO2. At the potential of 0.1 V, the current density of AC-NCO2 was 8.34 mA cm 2, two times higher than the bare AC. Among the AC-NCO, AC-NCO2 exhibited the highest performance. It is of critical importance to carefully balance the ratio of active NiCO2O4 and conductive active carbon. Either too low NiCo2O4 content (ACeNCOe1) or too higher (ACeNCOe3) gave inferior electrocatalytic performance.
EIS analysis was employed to separate the various resistances; the Nyquist plot was presented in Fig. 5b. The equivalent circuit methodwas usually adopted [32], whichwas shown in Fig. S1 using a reported EIS model. The equivalent circuit was consisted of an
and NiCo2O4 modified AC. Lines marked as ‘Cal’ were fitting data from the equivalent
external ohmic resistance mainly due to the electrolyte between the counter electrode and the air-cathode surface (Ro), a diffusion resistance that was an electronic resistance of the current collector and contact resistances (Rd), a charge transfer resistance (Rct), double layer capacitances (Cdl), pore adsorption capacitance (Cad) distributed between the ohmic and Faradic processes, and a Warburg impedance (W). Table 1 listed all the calculated resistances. Ro of all the cathodes were similar due to the same cell configuration. The Rct of AC-NCO1, AC-NCO2 and AC-NCO3 were 0.9369 U,
Fig. 6. (a) Tafel plots of AC cathodes with different content of NiCo2O4. The potential window (b) Linear fitting of from 80 mV to 100 mV. (ced) Rotating-disk voltammograms of the AC (c) the potential of 0.8 V (j 1 vs. u 1/2).
0.7926 U and 1.231 U, respectively, much smaller than that of bare AC (1.924U). The incorporation of active material NiCo2O4 into the conductive carbon significantly accelerates the ORR process and lowers the resistance [33]. The Rd of AC is more than twice larger than AC-NCO. It was reported that the large pore size and pore volume can serve as ion-buffering reservoir to minimize diffusion resistance to the interior surface, leading to the acceleration of ion diffusion and the reduce of Rd [33]. The lowest total resistance of AC-NCO2 (9.723 U) was found among AC-NCO, further corroborates
ranges from open circuit potential to the overpotential of 100 mV. Scan rate: 1 mV s 1; and AC-NiCo2O4 (d) in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. (e) KouteckyeLevich plot at
the least polarization resistance and highest overall performance as illustrated in Fig. 4.
The total resistance of AC-NCO2 was comparable to Cu support on AC (10.8 U), and the Rct of AC-NCO2 decreased by 43% compared to Cu/AC (1.381 U) [34,35]. It can be expected that the AC-NCO would exhibit improved performance compared to AC.

sections.heading: 3.4. Kinetics of ORR
sections.text:
Tafel equationwas employed to determine the exchange current density. Tafel plot of four cathodes were shown in Fig. 6a, and a linear region (overpotential of 80 mVe100 mV with R2 > 0.99) was extracted. The linear fitting results were listed in Table 2. The exchange current densities were ordered as followings: AC-NCO2 (25.49 A cm 2) > AC-NCO1 (21.98 A cm 2) > ACNCO3(17.07 A cm 2) > AC(6.79 A cm 2). A higher value io implied a facile and fast reaction with lower activation barrier. The Tafel analysis was consistent with the LSV and EIS. The results showed that adding appropriate amount of NiCo2O4 could lower the resistance and accelerate the kinetics, which finally contribute to the improved performance of MPD [36].
The ORR kinetics and mechanism were further analyzed by the RDE measurement. The number of electron transfer of bare AC and AC-NCO2 during ORR were calculated by Koutecky-Levic (KeL) equation [37]. 1=j ¼ 1=ðnAFkC0Þ 1 . 0:62nAFD2=30 v 1=6C0u1=2 (1)
where F is the Faraday constant, D0 is the diffusion coefficient(1.86 10 5 cm2 s 1), A is the area of the glassy carbon electrode, n is the kinematic viscosity of the electrolyte(0.01008 cm2 s 1), C0 is the concentration of O2 in the electrolyte (1.2 mM for saturated O2) [38], and k is the electron transfer rate constant.
Fig. 6ced showed the voltammograms of AC and AC-NCO2, respectively. The corresponding K-L plots (1/j vs. u 1/2) at 0.8 V were illustrated in Fig. 6e. The electron transfer number (n) during ORR of bare AC and AC-NCO2 were calculated to be 2.58 and 3.72, respectively. The higher value of n of AC-NCO2 implied a more efficient pathway to reduce oxygen, and this observation was consistent with finding detailed above.
In Fig. 6c, two stages of limiting current were observed on bare AC at around 0.4 and 0.6 V, respectively, suggesting the electrocatalytic reduction of oxygen proceeds via a two-step process [39].
O2ðadÞ þ H2Oþ 2e /HO2 þ OH (2a)
HO2 þ H2Oþ 2e /3OH (2b)
By contrast, from the oxygen reduction profile recorded at ACNCO2 electrode (Fig. 6d), one can see that there is only one stage with a much better defined current density plateau than those obtained at AC (Fig. 6c). In addition, the limiting current density at each rotation rate is larger than that of the second plateau obtained from AC. Such RDE features indicate that the ORR on AC-NiCo2O4 electrode proceeds via themost efficient four-electron process [39]:
O2ðadÞ þ 2H2Oþ 4e /4OH (3) Xiao et al. discovered that the transfer number for oxygen reduction on the NiCo2O4 catalyst varied from 3.5 to 4.0 [29]. Zhang et al. also reported the electron transfer number was about 3.80 for NiCo2O4-rGO Hybrid [40]. It suggested that the ORR pathway of ACNCO2 mainly proceeded via a four-electron pathway like Pt/C.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, we developed a porous urchin-like NiCo2O4 using a simple hydrothermal method. Modifying bare carbon with prepared NiCo2O4 would dramatically improve its electrochemical performance. The ratio of NiCo2O4 to carbonwas carefully balanced to achieve optimal performance. MPC with NiCo2O4 modified carbon showed a remarkable maximum power density of 1730 ± 14 mW m 2, which was comparable to the commercial precious Pt/C. The electrochemical characterization showed that the charge transfer resistance was significantly reduced due to the enhanced kinetics. And a four-electron pathway of oxygen reduction has been recovered on the NiCo2O4 modified carbon.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data related to this article can be found at http:// dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.11.003.

metadata.abstractText: A nano urchin-like NiCo2O4 has been successfully synthesized via a facile and scalable hydrothermal method. A NiCo2O4 modified active carbon air cathode was designed, optimized and fabricated. The maximum power density of the microbial fuel cell with newly developed cathode is 2.28 time higher than bare active carbon and is comparable to the commercial available Pt/C, reaching 1730 ± 14 mWm 2. The modified active carbon showed remarkable improvement in activity towards the oxygen reduction reaction, which was due to the lower charger transfer, lower activation barrier, and higher exchange current density. Electrochemical evaluation showed a direct four-electron the oxygen reduction reaction on NiCo2O4 modified active carbon, compared to a two-stage process on bare active carbon. The nonprecious NiCo2O4 could be considered as a promising alternative to the costly Pt. © 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
